args.help: Suppress diagnostic output

subcommands.name: run
subcommands.about:
Run a JavaScript or TypeScript program, or a task or script.

By default all programs are run in sandbox without access to disk, network or ability to spawn subprocesses.
  [38;5;245mdeno run https://examples.deno.land/hello-world.ts[39m

Grant permission to read from disk and listen to network:
  [38;5;245mdeno run --allow-read --allow-net jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m

Grant permission to read allow-listed files from disk:
  [38;5;245mdeno run --allow-read=/etc jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m

Grant all permissions:
  [38;5;245mdeno run -A jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m

Specifying the filename '-' to read the file from stdin.
  [38;5;245mcurl https://examples.deno.land/hello-world.ts | deno run -[39m

[33mRead more:[39m [36mhttps://docs.deno.com/go/run[39m

subcommands.name: serve
subcommands.about:
Run a server defined in a main module

The serve command uses the default exports of the main module to determine which servers to start.

Start a server defined in server.ts:
  [38;5;245mdeno serve server.ts[39m

Start a server defined in server.ts, watching for changes and running on port 5050:
  [38;5;245mdeno serve --watch --port 5050 server.ts[39m

[33mRead more:[39m [36mhttps://docs.deno.com/go/serve[39m

subcommands.name: add
subcommands.about:
Add dependencies to your configuration file.
  [38;5;245mdeno add jsr:@std/path[39m

You can also add npm packages:
  [38;5;245mdeno add npm:react[39m

Or multiple dependencies at once:
  [38;5;245mdeno add jsr:@std/path jsr:@std/assert npm:chalk[39m

args.name: packages
args.help: List of packages to add

args.name: dev
args.help: Add as a dev dependency

args.name: allow-scripts
args.help:
Allow running npm lifecycle scripts for the given packages
  [38;5;245mNote: Scripts will only be executed when using a node_modules directory (`--node-modules-dir`)[39m

subcommands.name: remove
subcommands.about:
Remove dependencies from the configuration file.
  [38;5;245mdeno remove @std/path[39m

You can remove multiple dependencies at once:
  [38;5;245mdeno remove @std/path @std/assert[39m

args.name: packages
args.help: List of packages to remove

subcommands.name: bench
subcommands.about:
Run benchmarks using Deno's built-in bench tool.

Evaluate the given files, run all benches declared with 'Deno.bench()' and report results to standard output:
  [38;5;245mdeno bench src/fetch_bench.ts src/signal_bench.ts[39m

If you specify a directory instead of a file, the path is expanded to all contained files matching the glob [36m{*_,*.,}bench.{js,mjs,ts,mts,jsx,tsx}[39m:
  [38;5;245mdeno bench src/[39m

[33mRead more:[39m [36mhttps://docs.deno.com/go/bench[39m

subcommands.name: compile
subcommands.about:
Compiles the given script into a self contained executable.

  [38;5;245mdeno compile --allow-read --allow-net jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno compile --output file_server jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m

Any flags specified which affect runtime behavior will be applied to the resulting binary.

This allows distribution of a Deno application to systems that do not have Deno installed.
Under the hood, it bundles a slimmed down version of the Deno runtime along with your
JavaScript or TypeScript code.

Cross-compiling to different target architectures is supported using the [36m--target[39m flag.
On the first invocation with deno will download the proper binary and cache it in [36m$DENO_DIR[39m.

subcommands.name: coverage
subcommands.about:
Print coverage reports from coverage profiles.

Collect a coverage profile with deno test:
  [38;5;245mdeno test --coverage=cov_profile[39m

Print a report to stdout:
  [38;5;245mdeno coverage cov_profile[39m

Include urls that start with the file schema and exclude files ending with [36mtest.ts[39m and [36mtest.js[39m,
for an url to match it must match the include pattern and not match the exclude pattern:
  [38;5;245mdeno coverage --include="^file:" --exclude="test\.(ts|js)" cov_profile[39m

Write a report using the lcov format:
  [38;5;245mdeno coverage --lcov --output=cov.lcov cov_profile/[39m

Generate html reports from lcov:
  [38;5;245mgenhtml -o html_cov cov.lcov[39m

[33mRead more:[39m [36mhttps://docs.deno.com/go/coverage[39m

subcommands.name: install
subcommands.about:
Installs dependencies either in the local project or globally to a bin directory.

[32mLocal installation[39m

Add dependencies to the local project's configuration ([38;5;245mdeno.json / package.json[39m) and installs them
in the package cache. If no dependency is specified, installs all dependencies listed in the config file.
If the [38;5;245m--entrypoint[39m flag is passed, installs the dependencies of the specified entrypoint(s).

  [38;5;245mdeno install[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno install jsr:@std/bytes[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno install npm:chalk[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno install --entrypoint entry1.ts entry2.ts[39m

[32mGlobal installation[39m

If the [1m--global[22m flag is set, installs a script as an executable in the installation root's bin directory.

  [38;5;245mdeno install --global --allow-net --allow-read jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno install -g https://examples.deno.land/color-logging.ts[39m

To change the executable name, use [36m-n[39m/[36m--name[39m:
  [38;5;245mdeno install -g --allow-net --allow-read -n serve jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m

The executable name is inferred by default:
  - Attempt to take the file stem of the URL path. The above example would
    become [38;5;245mfile_server[39m.
  - If the file stem is something generic like [38;5;245mmain[39m, [38;5;245mmod[39m, [38;5;245mindex[39m or [38;5;245mcli[39m,
    and the path has no parent, take the file name of the parent path. Otherwise
    settle with the generic name.
  - If the resulting name has an [38;5;245m@...[39m suffix, strip it.

To change the installation root, use [36m--root[39m:
  [38;5;245mdeno install -g --allow-net --allow-read --root /usr/local jsr:@std/http/file-server[39m

The installation root is determined, in order of precedence:
  - [38;5;245m--root[39m option
  - [38;5;245mDENO_INSTALL_ROOT[39m environment variable
  - [38;5;245m$HOME/.deno[39m

These must be added to the path manually if required.

subcommands.name: uninstall
subcommands.about:
Uninstalls a dependency or an executable script in the installation root's bin directory.
  [38;5;245mdeno uninstall @std/dotenv chalk[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno uninstall --global file_server[39m

To change the installation root, use [36m--root[39m flag:
  [38;5;245mdeno uninstall --global --root /usr/local serve[39m

The installation root is determined, in order of precedence:
  - [38;5;245m--root[39m option
  - [38;5;245mDENO_INSTALL_ROOT[39m environment variable
  - [38;5;245m$HOME/.deno[39m

args.help: Remove globally installed package or module

subcommands.name: outdated
subcommands.about:
Find and update outdated dependencies.
By default, outdated dependencies are only displayed.

Display outdated dependencies:
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --compatible[39m

Update dependencies:
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update --latest[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update[39m

Filters can be used to select which packages to act on. Filters can include wildcards (*) to match multiple packages.
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update --latest "@std/*"[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update --latest "react*"[39m
Note that filters act on their aliases configured in deno.json / package.json, not the actual package names:
  Given "foobar": "npm:react@17.0.0" in deno.json or package.json, the filter "foobar" would update npm:react to
  the latest version.
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update --latest foobar[39m
Filters can be combined, and negative filters can be used to exclude results:
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update --latest "@std/*" "!@std/fmt*"[39m

Specific version requirements to update to can be specified:
  [38;5;245mdeno outdated --update @std/fmt@^1.0.2[39m

args.name: filters
args.help: Filters selecting which packages to act on. Can include wildcards (*) to match multiple packages. If a version requirement is specified, the matching packages will be updated to the given requirement.

subcommands.name: lsp
subcommands.about:
The 'deno lsp' subcommand provides a way for code editors and IDEs to interact with Deno
using the Language Server Protocol. Usually humans do not use this subcommand directly.
For example, 'deno lsp' can provide IDEs with go-to-definition support and automatic code formatting.

How to connect various editors and IDEs to 'deno lsp': https://docs.deno.com/go/lsp

subcommands.name: lint
subcommands.about:
Lint JavaScript/TypeScript source code.

  [38;5;245mdeno lint[39m
  [38;5;245mdeno lint myfile1.ts myfile2.js[39m

Print result as JSON:
  [38;5;245mdeno lint --json[39m

Read from stdin:
  [38;5;245mcat file.ts | deno lint -[39m
  [38;5;245mcat file.ts | deno lint --json -[39m

List available rules:
  [38;5;245mdeno lint --rules[39m

To ignore specific diagnostics, you can write an ignore comment on the preceding line with a rule name (or multiple):
  [38;5;245m// deno-lint-ignore no-explicit-any[39m
  [38;5;245m// deno-lint-ignore require-await no-empty[39m

To ignore linting on an entire file, you can add an ignore comment at the top of the file:
  [38;5;245m// deno-lint-ignore-file[39m

[33mRead more:[39m [36mhttps://docs.deno.com/go/lint[39m

args.help: Write a JUnit XML test report to PATH. Use '-' to write to stdout which is the default when PATH is not provided

args.name: reporter
args.help: Select reporter to use. Default to 'pretty'

args.name: hide-stacktraces
args.help: Hide stack traces for errors in failure test results.

args.name: env-file
args.help:
Load environment variables from local file
  [38;5;245mOnly the first environment variable with a given key is used.
  Existing process environment variables are not overwritten, so if variables with the same names already exist in the environment, their values will be preserved.
  Where multiple declarations for the same environment variable exist in your .env file, the first one encountered is applied. This is determined by the order of the files you pass as arguments.[39m

args.name: ext
args.help: Set content type of the supplied file

args.name: unstable
args.help: Enable all unstable features and APIs. Instead of using this flag, consider enabling individual unstable features

subcommands.name: types
subcommands.about:
Print runtime TypeScript declarations.

  [38;5;245mdeno types > lib.deno.d.ts[39m

The declaration file could be saved and used for typing information.

subcommands.name: upgrade
subcommands.about:
Upgrade deno executable to the given version.

[32mLatest[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m

[32mSpecific version[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m [38;5;245m1.45.0[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m [38;5;245m1.46.0-rc.1[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m [38;5;245m9bc2dd29ad6ba334fd57a20114e367d3c04763d4[39m

[32mChannel[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m [38;5;245mstable[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m [38;5;245mrc[39m
  [1mdeno upgrade[22m [38;5;245mcanary[39m

The version is downloaded from [38;5;245mhttps://dl.deno.land[39m and is used to replace the current executable.

If you want to not replace the current Deno executable but instead download an update to a
different location, use the [36m--output[39m flag:
  [38;5;245mdeno upgrade --output $HOME/my_deno[39m

[33mRead more:[39m [36mhttps://docs.deno.com/go/upgrade[39m

args.name: output
args.help: The path to output the updated version to

args.name: dry-run
args.help: Perform all checks without replacing old exe

args.name: force
args.help: Replace current exe even if not out-of-date

args.name: version-or-hash-or-channel
args.help: Version [38;5;245m(v1.46.0)[39m, channel [38;5;245m(rc, canary)[39m or commit hash [38;5;245m(9bc2dd29ad6ba334fd57a20114e367d3c04763d4)[39m

args.name: cert
